importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The first dhow was intercepted on October 18, 2025, marking the start of the drug seizure operation and the beginning of the 48-hour operation window.
The U.S. Central Command publicly congratulated the operation on October 21, 2025, highlighting the international significance and coordination of the maritime interdiction effort.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The operations took place over a 48-hour period between October 18 and October 20, 2025, emphasizing the speed and coordination of the naval interdiction efforts.

keyTakeAways: The Pakistani navy, in coordination with the Combined Maritime Forces (CMF), intercepted two vessels in the Arabian Sea, seizing narcotics worth nearly $1 billion.
The first dhow intercepted on October 18, 2025, carried over 2 tonnes of crystal methamphetamine (ICE) valued at $822.4 million.
The second dhow, intercepted less than 48 hours later, carried 350 kg of ICE valued at $140 million and 50 kg of cocaine valued at $10 million.
The vessels were identified as having no nationality, suggesting possible international smuggling routes.
The operation was part of a Saudi-led Combined Task Force 150 under the CMF, highlighting multi-national collaboration in combating maritime drug trafficking.
The U.S. Central Command praised the operation as one of the most successful narcotics seizures in CMF history.
The CMF is a 47-nation naval alliance responsible for monitoring over 3.2 million square miles of maritime areas to prevent smuggling.
The Pakistani navy emphasized its commitment to regional maritime security and global peace through this operation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Pakistan Navy, operating under the Saudi-led Combined Maritime Forces Task Force 150, successfully intercepted two unidentified dhows in the Arabian Sea over a 48-hour period in early October 2025. The first dhow was boarded on October 18 and yielded over 2 tonnes of crystal methamphetamine valued at $822.4 million. A second dhow, intercepted less than 48 hours later, carried 350 kg of ICE worth $140 million and 50 kg of cocaine worth $10 million. The vessels were identified as having no nationality, suggesting cross-border smuggling. The operation, which was praised by U.S. Central Command as one of the most successful in CMF history, exemplifies the effectiveness of multi-national naval cooperation in combating maritime drug trafficking. The Pakistan Navy emphasized its commitment to regional and global maritime security through this operation.
title: Pakistan navy seizes drugs worth nearly $1bn in the Arabian Sea
